With continuously increasing capital, he plans to purchase stock directly from the factory. This will reduce his expense and he will be able to become a supplier in the area.

With his business, Peter is able to provide clothing to the community at an affordable price. He has also been able to bring products closer to other small business people. This enables them to save on transportation costs of having to go to the city for restocking. Mr. G. supports an orphanage with over 60 children in his home community in Central province. Within Malaba he is an active member of his church, supporting various church activities in the community.

He is a very hard working gentlemen who has repaid his loan with PEMCI timely. He is worth supporting.

loans.use: To improve his clothing business

loans.name: Mirriam

texts.en:
Mirriam M. is a single mother of two young girls. Like many young women in Kenya and in Africa at large, she is a primary school dropout due to lack of money to pay for her fees. She started her business in the year 2001 with initial capital of four dollars from her husband. They have since divorced.

With the requested loan of $300, she plans to increase her stock of assorted household items. Mirriam's business even takes her to the neighbouring country of Uganda. She sells household goods such as blankets, cooking pans, detergents, etc. at reasonable prices from Kenya.

Miriam depends on her business for her livelihood and to educate her daughters and pay for their general living expenses. She is an optimist and believes in what she is doing. She looks forward to opening a shop in Mbale, Uganda one day.

Mirriam's hard work is an inspiration for others in her community. It's amazing the amount of goods she and other vendors are able to carry and the long distances they travel. One can only admire their determination to fight on and overcome poverty. One can only be humbled by their sheer determination. Truly worth support by Kiva Partners.

loans.use: Buy stock for household items business

loans.name: Horacio

texts.en:
Mr Muniz is a true vendor. He currently sells fried pork rind, however his sales depend on the season. Another big seller for him is corn on the cob. The effort he puts into his business is evident in the dozens of clients that buy from him. He says, "I don't like to waste time, because it's very valuable to me. That's why I have a variety of products and when one runs low, I immediately begin to sell the other. At this time, I need a truck to outfit for sales. I really need it and so I am asking for a $1200 loan."

Translated by Bianca Vargas, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. M. es comerciante de corazón pues actualmente tiene la venta de chicharrones, sin embargo lo que vende va con la temporada, otra de sus ventas fuertes es la de elotes. Las ganas que le pone al comercio se ven reflejadas en las decenas de clientes que acuden con él. "No me gusta perder el tiempo para mi es muy valioso, por eso tengo variedad de productos cuando se empieza a escasear un producto inmediatamente empiezo a trabajar en el otro, en este momento necesito una camioneta para acondicionarla, me hace mucha falta por eso les pido un monto de $1,200.00 dlls

loans.use: To buy a truck from which to sell product.

loans.name: María De La Luz

texts.en:
María de la Luz is married and has been making and selling decorative handicrafts for the past 15 years. This occupation has helped her provide for and educate her eight children. Her children are now grown and she lives alone with her husband, who is sick and cannot work. The income that Doña María receives from her work is the only income for this household. One of her daughters helps her make her products. María is asking for a loan of $375, which she will use to buy the materials she needs to continue her work.

You can help this family. Doña María is very willing to work, but she needs your collaboration. This is your opportunity to help to someone in need, have no doubts, her future is in your hands.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María de la Luz es casada, desde hace 15 años hace y vende manualidades, este oficio le ha ayudado a darles sustento y educación a sus ocho hijos. Sus hijos ya están grandes y vive sola con su esposo que está enfermo y no puede trabajar, por lo que el ingreso que recibe Doña María por su trabajo es el único para este hogar, una de sus hijas le ayuda en la elaboración de sus productos. La señora María solicita un préstamo de $ 375 dólares que utilizará en la compra de los materiales que necesita para continuar con su labor.

Tú puedes ayudar a esta familia, Doña María está muy dispuesta a trabajar pero necesita de tu colaboración, es tu oportunidad de ayudar a quien más lo necesita, no lo dudes más, su futuro está en tus manos.

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Brenda Janeth

texts.en:
Brenda is a very dynamic woman. She is married and has two small children. The oldest child attends kindergarten and the younger one is about to start kindergarten. The income that her husband receives is not enough to cover all the family’s expenses and make the payments on their house. For this reason, Brenda started selling cosmetics so that she could help support her family. Now she needs your help. She wants to buy a stock of products in order to sell them and achieve a better income. She is seeking a loan of $250 to be able to do this.

Brenda and her family need your collaboration. It is in your hands to help this family. Don’t leave it for another day--today is your opportunity to help, decide to do it.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Brenda es una mujer muy activa, es casada y tiene dos hijos pequeños, el más grande de ellos asiste a la escuela preescolar y el pequeño esta a punto de entrar. El ingreso que recibe su esposo es muy poco para solventar todos los gastos familiares, además del pago que están haciendo para adquirir su casa, por esto Brenda inició con la venta de cosméticos, y de esta manera apoyar a su familia. Ahora ella necesita de tu ayuda, quiere surtirse de productos para poder venderlos y obtener un mejor ingreso, y solicita un préstamo de $ 250 dólares con este fin.

Brenda y su familia necesitan de tu colaboración, en tus manos esta el poder apoyar a esta familia, no lo dejes para otro día, hoy es tu oportunidad de ayudar, decídete.

loans.use: To buy a stock of products

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio has been working for a long time in the business of selling shoes. He used to have a shop in his own house, but when his marriage ended, his wife kept the business and Antonio had to start over again. Little by little, he opened a new shoe store. Now that he has his own business, he needs a loan of $1,200.00, which he will use to fill many of the orders that he already has, and to provide better service to his clients.

Antonio really wants to get ahead and he knows that with a little bit of help he can achieve great things. He expects to repay the loan over a period of 6 to 12 months. You can contribute to the growth of this business. Be an important part of Antonio’s life, he will be sincerely grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Antonio tiene mucho tiempo en el negocio de venta de zapatos, anteriormente tenía su local en su propio domicilio, pero después de la disolución de su matrimonio, su esposa se quedó con el negocio y Antonio tuvo que empezar de nuevo, poco a poco logró abrir otra zapatería, ahora que ya tiene su propio negocio necesita de un préstamo de $1200 dólares que utilizará para surtir muchos de los pedidos que ya tiene, y para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

Antonio tiene muchos deseos de superación, y sabe que con un poco de ayuda puede lograr grandes cosas, y espera devolver el préstamo en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses, tú puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio, sé parte importante en la vida de Antonio, él te lo agradece sinceramente.

loans.use: To buy inventory

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida is a single mother of two children who are 19 and 25 years old. In August 2004, she began selling electronics and accessories. Adelaida rented a shop and began selling televisions and stereos by order. Over time, she realized that when people can see products in the store, the products sell more quickly. For this reason, she is requesting a loan of $375 to buy a larger inventory, which will improve her sales and help her business to grow.

Adelaida is a very enterprising woman who needs your loan in order to get ahead and help her children by providing them with education so that they can have a better future. You can contribute to this family’s wellbeing. Decide to help them, they will be very grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Adelaida es madre soltera de dos hijos de 19 y 25 años. Inició en agosto de 2004 con la venta de aparatos electrónicos y accesorios para los mismos, para poder ofrecer sus productos. Adelaida rentó un local y empezó ofreciendo televisiones y grabadoras por pedido, con el tiempo se ha dado cuenta de que cuando los clientes ven los productos se venden de una manera más rápida, por lo que ahora solicita el préstamo de $375 dólares para la compra de mercancía, lo que hará incrementar su inventario, mejorar sus ventas y hacer crecer en su negocio.

Adelaida es una mujer emprendedora que necesita de tu préstamo para poder superarse y poder sacar adelante a sus hijos brindándoles educación para que puedan tener un mejor futuro, tú puedes contribuir a que ella y su familia tengan un mayor bienestar, decídete ayúdalos, te estarán muy agradecidos

loans.use: To buy product inventory

loans.name: María Belem

texts.en:
Maria began selling home products two years ago, when her husband was unemployed. Her family went through very difficult times and there were arguments over money. From that moment she decided to work, but her husband wouldn’t let her because he was afraid she wouldn’t be able to take good care of their 8 year-old son. Out of desperation to help support her husband in a way that wouldn’t offend him, she began selling from catalogues since that wouldn’t interfere with her household duties. María began to supply her first orders by using her husband’s severance pay. She reinvested the earnings by selling products physically, instead of from a catalog, and was able to achieve better results with her clients.

María needs a loan of $375 to buy inventory because demand for her products has increased recently. You can collaborate in the growth of this home business and provide support to this family. Decide to help, they will be very appreciative.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

María comenzó con las ventas hace dos años, cuando su esposo fue desempleado, su familia pasó por momentos muy difíciles y se presentaron discusiones familiares por motivos económicos. A partir de ese momento ella decidió trabajar, pero su esposo no se lo permitió por temor a que descuidara a su hijo de 8 años; en su desesperación por apoyar a su esposo y que éste no se ofendiera inició con la venta por catálogo ya que esto no le impedía llevar a cabo sus ocupaciones del hogar. Así María, empezó a surtir sus primeros pedidos con el dinero de la liquidación de su esposo, y reinvertía las ganancias para ofrecer sus productos físicamente y de esta manera obtuvo mejores resultados de sus clientes.

María requiere un préstamo de $375 dólares para la compra de mercancía ya que la demanda de sus productos se ha incrementado últimamente. Tú puedes colaborar en el crecimiento de este negocio, y apoyar a esta familia, decídete a ayudar, ellos te lo agradecerán.

loans.use: To buy product inventory

loans.name: Ràúl Cesar

texts.en:
Mr. Cesar has spent most of his life dedicated to tailoring. He says it is a family business; his wife and children work with him. "I have very little fabric to use. I need more material to be able to continue to fill my clients' orders. I'm asking for a loan of $1,200."

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Don Cesar lleva toda una vida dedicándose al oficio de la sastrería, es el negocio de la familia como dice el, su esposa y sus hijos forman parte del equipo de trabajo. "Tengo muy poca tela de donde cortar requiero de una cantidad mayor de material para poder seguir con los encargos de mis clientes solicito un préstamo de $1,200.00 dlls

loans.use: To buy material for my work.

loans.name: Clemente

texts.en: In Choluteca, most people know me as Don Clemen. I have been selling men’s clothing, men’s stockings and cooking apparel for two years. I visit different sites and offices to make my sales, and people can purchase goods as they need. I also have a small post at the market, where my wife sells ladies’ shoes and sandals. Our income is used to pay for our children’s education and food.

loans.use: Purchase of sandals, glasses, towels, etc.

loans.name: Jose Izabel

texts.en: I have four children and my business is the sale of common consumer goods like bread, coffee, sugar, milk, eggs, and all other basic food products. My business is located within my home and my entire family runs it. We work in shifts since my children go to school in the morning and afternoon. Thanks to my business I have been able to give my family a good education; my goal is for them to graduate from college and improve their level of education and standard of life.

loans.use: Purchase of refreshments, bread, eggs, coffee, candy, milk, churros, etc.

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.en:
My business is the buying and selling of gold to be used to make jewelry such as rings, chains and earrings. My best clients are young professionals who enjoy dressing sharp and wearing jewelry. As Mother's Day approaches, I need to increase my inventory so I can offer my clients more selection for gifts. The extra income from sales will be used to help my children's education and cover expenses at home.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi negocio es la compra y venta de enchape de oro, actualmente en nuestro medio se usa mas las joyas de enchape ya sean anillos, cadenas, aritos. Mis mejores clientas son jovenes que trabajan en oficinas y les gusta andar presentables en su vestimenta y joyas. Por acercarse el dia de la madre necesito surtir el inventario para poder ofrecer a mis clientes variedad para que ellos puedan regalar. Los ingresos que me genera este negocio son para ayudar a mis hijos en sus estudios y colaborar con los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Buy gold to make earrings, chains, rings and other jewelry.

loans.name: Oralia

texts.en:
I am a single mom and my son helps me sell our products. I run the business out of my house. My clients are neighbors and people who pay me to sell products in their areas. I need to buy more ingredients because my clientele is growing due to the high-quality products I sell.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Soy madre soltera, tengo un hijo el que me ayuda a vender nuestros productos, este negocio lo tengo en mi casa, mis clientes son vecinos de mi comunidad y otra personas que me compran para vender en los lugares donde viven. Neceisto comprar mas producto ya que mi clientela ha aumentado por el buen producto que les ofrezco.

loans.use: Buy products like milk, cheese, custard and butter.

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.en:
My name is Magdalena and two years ago I decided to sell clothing for men, women and children. I also sell jewelry such as rings, chains and earrings. My sales are from client-direct orders, so they are safe. As Mother's Day and summer are approaching, I need to provide warm-weather products like bathing suits, sandals, shorts, T-shirts and some jewelry for gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Me llamo Magdalena y me dedico a vender ropa para damas, caballero y ninos desde hace dos anos, tambien vendo anillos, cadenas y anillos de enchape de oro. Mis ventas son por encargos de mis clientes, por lo que mis ventas son seguras, en este momento por acercarse el verano y dia de la madre necesito surtir mis productos con ropa de verano como trajes de bano, sandalias, shorts, camisetas y algunas joyas para regalos.

loans.use: Buy clothing such as shirts, pants, shorts, T-shirts and jewelry accessories.

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.en:
I have dedicated myself to taxi driving for four years, helping people on the streets and also favored clients who call my cell phone so I can pick them up personally and take them to their destination. At the moment my car has a few problems, and I need to change some parts and get new tires so I can continue to offer a good service.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace cuatro anos me dedico a este rubro, atiendo personas en las calles y tambien algunas personas de confianza que llaman a mi celular para que los transporte a su destino. En este momento mi carro tiene algunas fallas por lo que necesito cambiarle algunas piezas y las llantas para poder brindar un buen servicio.

loans.use: Vehicle repairs

loans.name: Mirna Liliam

texts.en:
I have four years of experience selling treats. I sell during afternoons and at night on the weekends. I prepare tortillas, tacos, enchiladas, bread with beans, carne asada and beverages to clients who enjoy my products. At times I'm left without ingredients to bake more goods. I need to be able to buy more ingredients and sell more of my products so I can increase my income and be able to provide for my children.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo cuatro anos de dedicarme a la venta de comidas, comunmente conocidas como golosinas, vendo por las tardes y los fines de semana en las noches. Preparo tortillas con quesillo, tacos, enchiladas, panes con frijoles, carne asada y refrescos naturales, a mis clientes les gusta mi comida y a veces me quedo sin produco para elaborar mas comida, por lo que necesito comprar mas producto y vender mas, asi mis ingresos van aumentar y voy a poder ayudar mas a mis hijos.

loans.use: Buy ingredients like meat, tortilla, flour, lard, condiments, chicken, fruits, etc.

loans.name: Iris Suyapa

texts.en:
I have dedicated myself to the preparation of women's clothing for three years. I make blouses, skirts and dresses for people who request my services. Currently I have sufficient work because some schools have asked me to make blouses for their students, since I can sell it to them at lower prices than the stores. At the moment I need to buy fabrics to finish the order and then make clothes for the summer. My children help me put bottons on the clothes, which has helped me not have to delay the orders.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo 3 anos de dedicarme a la confeccion de ropa para damas, fabrico blusas, faldas, vestidos de personas que buscan mis servicios. Actualmente tengo bastante trabajo ya que algunas escuelas me pidieron les fabrique las blusas de los ninos, ya que les doy precios bajos comparados a los precios de tiendas. En este momento necesito comprar telas para terminar de entregar el pedido y luego fabricar otra ropa de verano. Mis hijos me ayudan a pegar los botones de las camisas lo que me ayuda para no retrasar los pedidos.

loans.use: Buy fabrics, threads, embroideries, buttons zippers, etc.

loans.name: Patrocinia

texts.en:
My name is Patrocinia, and I purchase and sell watches, chains, rings, and other products. At this time I need funds to be able to buy and sell products to my clients. Because of my age I need a job that sustains my personal expenses, including health. My clients are young office workers and businesses that purchase accessories to offer as gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Me llamo Patrocinia y me dedico a la compra y venta de relojes, aritos, cadenas, anillos y otros productos. En este momento necesito capital de trabajo para poder comprar productos y vender a mis clientes. Por mi edad necesito un trabajo que pueda cubrir mis gastos personales, y de salud. Mis clientes son jovenes de oficinas, o de negocios quienes me compran accesorios para embellecer su personalidad.

loans.use: Purchase of watches and plating accessories.

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.en:
My name is Maria Antonia, and I am a widowed mother of 3. Recently I lost my husband to an accident. This has forced me to seek a way of life in which I can sustain my family. I prepare food during the afternoons and weekends and work during the morning hours cleaning a company's office. At this time I need to strengthen my business now that I do not have any help and my children are attending school. I am an optimistic woman, and through my efforts I can further provide for my family's future.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Maria Antonia, tengo 3 hijos y soy viuda, recientemente perdi a mi esposo en un accidente lo que me ha hecho buscar la manera de mantener a mi familia, me dedico a preparar comidas por las tardes y fines de semana, tambien trabajo en horas de la manana en una empresa que me paga por el aseo de su local, ahora necesito fortalecer mas mi negocio ya que no tengo ayuda de nadie, y mis hijos se encuentran en la escuela. Soy una mujer optimista y se que poninedo de mi esfuerzo puedo sacar adelante a mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase seasonings, potatoes, meat, tortillas, beans, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Doris Suyapa

texts.en:
For four years I have sold clothes in my community's market. This market is the most visited in the city. This is an advantage for me; I can sell my clothes everyday. At this moment I want to expand my business by providing bathing suits, sandals, and sunglasses; thus, I can supply the locals, who frequent beaches, with summer clothes. My children help me on weekends--our most profitable time. Their participation is a way for them to contribute to familial expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace cuatro anos me dedico a la venta de ropa en el mercado de mi comunidad, este mercado es el mas visitado en la ciudad es una ventaja para mi, ya que todos los dias puedo vender mi ropa. En este momento quiero surtir el negocio con trajes de bano, sandalias, y lentes de sol ya que las personas siempre salen de paseo a las playas y comprar su ropa de verano. Mis hijos me ayudan los fines de semana que es cuando mas ventas tenemos, asi ellos tambien colaboraran con para poder cubrir con todos los gastos de la familia.

loans.use: Purchase shirts, pants, socks, undergarments, etc.

loans.name: Maria Benigna

texts.en:
I have sold cosmetics and lotions for a year. I sell these products through a catalog. This has created some difficulties because I do not have sufficient capital to be able to purchase products solicited by my clients. I seek new revenues to be able to attend to all my clients. I firmly believe that what I invest I will recuperate at the moment of sale to my clients. The revenue generated by sales helps me support my children's schooling.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un ano de vender cosmeticos y lociones, estas ventas las hago por encargo de catalogos, se me ha dificultado un poco porque no tengo suficiente capital para poder comprar productos que mis clientes me piden, es por lo que necesito capital de trabajo fresco para poder atender a todas las clientes, me siento segura porque lo que invierto lo recupero al momento de entregar el producto a mis clientes es por eso que lo hago de esta manera. Los ingresos que tengo de mis ventas me ayudan a mantener a mis hijos que se encuentra estudiando en escuelas.

loans.use: Purchase lipsticks, eye liners, tweezers, lotions, face powders, etc.

loans.name: Carlos Manuel

texts.en:
I have sold men's and women's products for a year. My clientele consists of neighbors and friends who solicit me and pay me weekly for all purchased products. During the summertime I want to purchase products for beachgoers, especially for the treatment of women's hair and skin, as well as sandals and sunglasses.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un ano de dedicarme a la venta de productos para dama y caballero, mi clientela son vecinos y amigos quienes me hacen pedidos y me pagan semanal por todos los productos que me compran. Ahorita en epoca de verano quiero comprar productos para las personas que visiten las playas, especialmente para mujeres tratamientos de pelo, piel, ademas comprar sandalias y lentes de sol.

loans.use: Purchase lotions, creams, deodorants, toothpaste.

loans.name: Glenda Experanza

texts.en:
I live in the city of Choluteca, and I sell used and new clothing. I offer my customers two options since some do not have sufficient resources to purchase new clothes. Together with my husband and two children we seek to expand our house. At this moment--thanks to God--my husband has a job, and, with my sales, together we supply and cover all the familial necessities.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Vivo en la ciudad de Choluteca y me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva y usada, tengo dos opciones para mis clientes ya que algunos de ellos no tienen suficientes recursos para poder comprar ropa nueva, entonces me compran ropa de segunda. Mi familia es de dos hijos, mi esposo juntos hemos buscado la manera de sacar adelante mi hogar, gracias a Dios en este momento mi esposo tiene trabajo y con mis ventas suplimos y cubrimos todas las necesidades familiares.

loans.use: Purchase towels, shirts, shorts, etc.

loans.name: Alexis Yovany

texts.en:
For four years now I have framed photographs, diplomas, etc. I attend to my business personally, and my clients are market vendors who sell mirrors and decorative picture frames, as well as single clients who desire to have photographs and diplomas framed. My business has generated enough revenue to sustain my family. However, I want to purchase material to expand my business now that I have begun to remodel my house. This new capital will help finalize construction.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace cuatro anos me dedico al enmarcado de cuadros, fotografias, diplomas y otros. Mi negocio lo atiendo personalmente y mis clientes son vendedores de mercado que venden espejos y cuadros decorativos, tambien a personas particulares que enmarcan fotografias y diplomas. Mi negocio me ha generado ingresos para mantener a mi familia, quiero comprar material para hacer mas trabajos ya que comence a remodelar mis casa y necesito capital para finalizar la obra.

loans.use: Purchase wood, glue, special cardboard, and glass.

loans.name: Sohar Gricelda

texts.en:
My name is Sohar, and I sell dry wood to my neighbors. In our community we use ovens to cook our food, tortillas, etc. For us it is cheaper to use ovens (not stoves), and this helps us conserve energy. My biggest clients are the people dedicated to manufacturing and selling tortillas. I need to maintain a great amount of wood, and buying in large quantity is cheaper. In this way I can obtain greater revenues to help my family.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Me llamo Sohar y me dedico a la venta de lena seca a mis vecinos, en nuestra comunidad usamos fogones para cocinar nuestros alimentos, las tortillas y otros. Para nosotros es mucho mas barato usar fogones que estufas y nos ayuda en la economia de nuestros hogares. Mis mayores clientes son las personas que se dedican a elaborar y vender tortillas es por lo que necesito mantener un buen numero de lena y comprando por cantidades grandes es mas barato, asi puedo obtener mejores ingresos para ayudar a mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase firewood.

loans.name: Salum

texts.en: R. operates a mobile shop in Dar es Salaam. He has been in this business for four years now. He plans to expand his business by adding varieties of products for sale. R. has undergone a business and entrepreneurship training from YOSEFO. He wants to apply the theory part of the training into reality. He is in need of USD 400 to implement his plan.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kassim

texts.en:
K. has been selling cold drinks along Mandela road in Dar es Salaam for three years now. He buys these drinks from wholesalers and resells them in his small retail shop located in a busy area of Mandela road.

K. could not afford a refrigerator, so he depends on ice blocks which he buys from the Coca-Cola Company. K. wants to improve his business by buying a refrigerator to keep the drinks cold. He therefore requests a loan of USD550 to buy a refrigerator.

loans.use: Buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the loan to expand my businesses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Mr. M. is 67 years old and in his second loan with PEMCI, but his first with Kiva. Robert is married with sixteen children. Some children are in school, and others are even married.

He is trained in business management and tailoring services by the promise land in Kakamega. His first loan of $150 was used to buy fabrics for his tailoring business. He has been in business since 1968 and has solely depended on his business for sustaining his family.

With the proposed loan from PEMCI of $300, he plans to increase his fabric stock and buy an additional sewing machine. Mr M. is full of life. Even at his age, he looks forward to opening up a local youth training centre in business and tailoring skills.

A staunch Catholic, Mr M. is an active member of his local church and the community. As a senior member of his community he has a lot to share with the young generation. He is worthy of the support of Kiva partners.

loans.use: To boost his tailoring business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes K. is 23 years old. She lost her mother in 2004 to the dreaded AIDS. She came from a single parent family. 

A womens group by the name WOFAK (Women Fighting AIDS in Kenya) knew her mother so they sponsored Agnes for hairdressing and beauty training at the Alternative School of Hairdressing from 2005 to 2006. Agnes was one of the best students and was offered employment at the Blue Yellow Hair Salon in Hurlingham. 

Agnes started saving and by the time she left her job to look after her younger sister, who is year years old and HIV positive, she had saved USD 357. With these savings, Agnes bought hair relaxing chemicals, rollers, a blowdryer, towels and some chairs.  She then rented a shop from where she has been operating. With her income, she is able to feed, educate and buy medicine for her sister. On a sad note Agnes and her 8 siblings (four brothers and four sisters) were disowned by her mother’s relatives after they learned that she was HIV positive. So after burying her mother, Agnes took full responsibility of raising her siblings.   
  
Agnes has been experiencing difficulties due to stiff competition from neighboring salons, which are fully equipped. A few clients have left. Agnes has been trying to do after-sales services, such as offering a free hair wash, in order to retain some of her clients. She senses that if they continue to leave, she will be left with no income to feed herself and her siblings. Agnes is therefore requesting a loan of USD 625 to help her purchase a dryer, steamer, blowdryer, four chairs, training dummy and a 14-inch television set. With this additional equipment, Agnes will be able to compete with her fellow competitors and hopes that with time she will win her clients back. She will also be able to give her customers quick and efficient service and in turn increase her income.

Due to the harsh situation that Agnes went through, i.e. rejection and neglect from her close relatives, Agnes has taken 2 orphaned girls and is training them in hairdressing. She has been able to overcome obstacles in her life and does not want girls in similar conditions to suffer like she did. 

After buying the equipment, Agnes will employ two other people. This will translate into higher income that will enable her to support her siblings. Agnes intends to repay the loan in 8–15 months.

loans.use: To purchase a dryer, steamer, blowdryer, four chairs, training dummy and a 14-inch television set.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice Atieno O. is 41 years old and married with 5 children. She also looks after 13 dependents: 10 are orphans. Three children are from his brother, who together with his wife died of AIDS in 2002. Another seven children are from another brother who had two wives, of which one passed away. The brother is currently on antiretroviral drugs (drugs that boost immunity of people living with HIV/AIDS). She is also living with her grandmother and her nephew (whose mother is Eunice’s sister) and depends on her for clothing and education.  
                                                                           
Eunice started her business in 1995 after having finished a hairdressing course from Pilkington College in Kampala, Uganda. There she got a certificate in hairdressing. After completion of her course, her husband bought her a dryer, blowdryer, rollers, five chairs, a sink and hair-relaxing chemicals so that she could start a salon. Her husband told her that he had loaned her the items so she had to pay him back. Since Eunice had already saved Ksh. 35,000 (USD 500) through the selling of clothes and shoes in 1993 and 1994, she had no problem repaying the items within two years. The business was doing well until  February this year when a fire broke out at her business premises. Seemingly good samaritans, who came in the pretext of helping her, stole her possessions including her dryer, blowdryer, sink, plastic chairs, mirrors and hair chemicals. They ransacked her salon completely. They even took away the door to her salon. She is repairing the damage done to her salon.   
     
Eunice is asking for a loan of USD 300 which she will repay within a period of 8-15 months. Eunice intends to replace the items which were stolen and hopefully continue to support her large family.

loans.use: to purchase a hairdryer, blowdryer, mirror, sink and rollers

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en:
Franklin is a 37 year old widower with four children living in the Kibera slums of Nairobi. Having not completed his secondary school education, Franklin decided to come to Nairobi from his home in the Kisii district to try his luck in the capital city. 

Fortunately, he had a cousin who owned a metal workshop.  He was able to assist with tasks at the workshop which gave him work exposure. After about 6 months he left and was employed at a firm named  Joaki Enterprises within the city. That was in 2000. Franklin was lucky and got a contract to make windows and doors for Ksh 17,000 (USD 243). With this kind of money, he decided that it was time to be on his own. Through his savings and the money he earned from the contract, Franklin started his own workshop in September 2005. Since then the business has been doing well and has enabled him to put his eldest daughter into a boarding school in Kakamega, the western part of Kenya.
                                    
The only impediment to Franklin’s business is that he doesn’t have a grinder and drilling machine. Quite often he borrows from neighboring workshops, which are sometimes not willing to loan their equipment. Time and money is wasted negotiating for the equipment. Lately he has been losing business due to the lack of machines. 

Therefore Franklin is kindly asking for a loan of USD 200 to enable him to purchase the grinder and drilling machines. The new additions to his business will allow him do his work quickly and efficiently. This will bring back his clients and he will get contracts to make windows, doors and other welding related work. Franklin sees this as a way of creating job opportunities and intends to employ two more people to help him at the workshop.  This is because he envisions that he will have more work from additional contracts.  The repayment period for the loan is 8-15 months.

loans.use: to purchase a grinder and drilling machine

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela Akeyo O. is 34 years old. She is married and has four children. They live within the Kibera slums of Nairobi. She also takes care of six orphans left behind by her brother who passed away in 2000 due to HIV/AIDS.

Initially, Pamela was employed at a salon where she was paid by commission for the work done.  However, the pay was little. She persevered because she had a large family looking up to her. Pamela saved some money from the two years she was employed, which she used to buy a second-hand blowdryer and dryer. Afterwards, through a village merry-go-round group for women, Pamela received Ksh 2,000 (USD 28) which she used to purchase combs, towels and a sink.

In 2003, Pamela started her own salon. Due to her skill in hairdressing, including braiding, weaving, perming (chemical application for hair straightening) and styling, the demand for her services has increased. She is therefore requesting a loan of USD 100 to enable her buy an additional blowdryer, four big chairs and two small chairs for the children. 

Because her clientele has increased, she wants them to be comfortable while waiting to be served. This means her clients who used to go to the neighboring salons because they got tired of waiting will now be served quickly. The outcome of this will be higher income. 

Through this, Pamela will be able to better support her family. The repayment period for her loan is between 8 and 15 months.

loans.use: to purchase a blowdryer and six chairs

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Food production is key to the development of Ghana's economy. Lydia is involved in food production on a commercial basis in her community. She won the "District Best Farmer" in coco yam production. She has been trained in the TEACH Lending skills programme of Kraban Support Foundation and is now able to keep records of her business venture.

loans.use: Farm Implements

loans.name: Rosaline Ambang

texts.en:
Born in 1967, Rosaline is a mother of four children. To her it was a dream come true when GHAPE outreached into her community and she received her first loan in 2004. With previous loans, she provided her community with fish, pork, manure and yams. Her goal is to build her self esteem and provide for her children.  

Given a loan of $400, she plans to increase her stock by stocking fish, reinforcing the pig fence and buying pig feed and medication. She plans to repay her loans with the sales from fish and her farming activities.  The hopes to save the money earned from her pigs. She is convinced her business will succeed because of her skills in the domain, the available market and the support from her group and center members.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first repayment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: the selling of fish and pig farming

loans.name: Otto Che

texts.en:
Otto is married and has seven children. His realization of the poor living condition endured by his family is his source of motivation to engage in income-generating activities.  This is his fourth time borrowing. With his three previous loans, he succeeded in providing his community with fresh raw food. Benefits from his investment were primarily used for tuition. He succeeded in reducing the number of times his children were sent out of class for a fee-drive. His immediate goal is to provide the basics of food, schooling and clothing to his family.

Given a loan of $400, he plans to buy seedlings, two piglets, and feed and set aside some money for vet services for the pigs. He plans to provide his community with fresh food at farm prices. His long term goal is to improve his housing situation.

He plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first repayment will four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: trading and farming

loans.name: Pamela Neh Akoso

texts.en:
Born in 1975, Pamela is a single mother of two children named Solange and Blaise. She perseveres in life although her boyfriend, who is the father of her kids, disappointed her. She took out her first loan in 2003, the same year she had her second baby. This is her fourth time borrowing. With her three previous loans she provided her community with fast-food services and fresh raw food from her farm. She is proud of having bought some kitchen utensils and paid her children’s fees.

Given a loan of $600, she plans to buy flour, sugar, oil, yeast, and cups to enhance her “achumbu” (convenient road side restaurant) activity.  The loan will also pay for labor to clear her farm and sticks to repair her existing pig fence. Her immediate goal is to continuously provide for her children while rendering the needed achumbu services to her community.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: trading and farming

loans.name: Alice Tifan

texts.en:
Alice is a mother of five children. The death of her father and the pain of watching some of her children miss an academic year due to a lack of money is the source of her motivation. Inspired by single mothers sponsoring their children in school, she took her first loan in 2004. Now this is her third time borrowing. With her previous two loans she succeeded in providing her community with food and manure. She is proud of having taken, managed, and repaid the loan while providing for some of her kids’ needs.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to buy six piglets, feed, sticks, as well as nails and zinc to repair the pig-fence.  She also wants to set aside money for vet services for the pigs. She plans to pay the loan installments with money she earns from the sale of manure and vegetables, of which she will cultivate with manure from her pig farm. She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: pig farming

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a married with three children. When he lost his job as a salesman at the Total petrol station in Kumba he welcomed unemployment as an opportunity to become self-employed. He traveled back to his native village and joined GHAPE in 2004. With his two previous loans he has succeeded in providing his community with fish, pork and manure.

Given a loan of $800, he plans to buy nine piglets, sticks to repair his fence, pig feed, and Belgo concentrate feed for fish. He is convinced he will succeed for because of his motivation, the skills he learned in trainings, the available market and his commitment to success. He plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: selling fish and pigs

loans.name: Pauline Na Gana

texts.en:
Pauline is a widow with six children. She needed something to distract her from her memories of the death of her husband and son. She joined GHAPE in 2005 and benefitted from the social support provided by the group and center members. With her prior two loans, she succeeded in providing her community with cassava and acquired new skills to deal with her grief. She is hoping to provide for her children, grandchildren and herself in times of sickness.

Given a loan of $500, she plans to buy piglets, feed, medication, and rent a piece of land for cassava cultivation. She plans to pay monthly installments with the money she earns from selling manure and from her previous harvest. She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: cultivation and trading

loans.name: Peter Agwo

texts.en:
Peter is a widower with five children. 

He joined GHAPE in 2004. With his two previous loans, he succeeded in providing his community with food. He is proud of having earned some money which he used for paying tuition for his children.

Given a loan of $200, he plans to buy piglets and fingerlings. He is optimistic given the fact that the supply of fish is limited and manure is always in great demand. He plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: selling fish and pigs

loans.name: Lydia Aseh

texts.en:
Lydia is a widow with six children. To provide for herself and the children, she had to start working very hard after the death of her husband. With her two previous loans she succeeded in providing her community with palm oil, manure and meat.

Given a loan of $300, she plans to buy piglets, sticks to reinforced the pig fence and tins of palm-oil. She plans to pay the monthly installments with sales of palm oil and vegetables.  The vegetables will be harvested from her vegetable garden, which is cultivated with manure from her pig farm. She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: selling palm oil and pig farming

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Hang is 47, her husband is Kim. They have 2 sons and 2 daughters between the ages of 9 and 24. Their 3 oldest children were forced to stop studying at school in order to work in another province to help support their famiL.. Their youngest daughter has just begun going to school.

They have no land except for their house. Hang has a small grocery store at her home and her husband drives a motorcycle taxi in order to make some money. Though they work hard, their income is onL. $11 per person/month. They believe that if they receive a loan for $75, they will increase the variety of goods they sell in their grocery store. They hope that they can improve their income through their grocery store. They promise to repay monthL..

loans.use: Increase the variety of goods in her grocery store at her house

loans.name: Bi

texts.en:
Bi is now 47, and Tu is her husband. They have a small house in the countryside with no land. Her husband raises pigs and fish but their income is still only $10/person/month.

They have three children; 2 daughters and a son. Ngoc Han, their oldest daughter, wants to attend university. Their other daughter is working in the city to help support her family. Their son is mentally retarded and must be cared for at home.

Bi needs a loan of $75 to use for her grocery store at home and to help her husband raise fish and pigs. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: Bi needs a loan so that she can sell some things in her grocery store at home and for her husband to raise fish

loans.name: Juliet Grace

texts.en:
Grace is in a very unique business not often operated by women in this part of the world. As such, she is viewed by many women in her community as a role model. Grace is a widow with six children. Five children are in secondary school, and one is working as a teacher. She is a high school dropout and hasn’t undergone any training.

She started her business in 1994 to support her family and school-going children after her husband died. This is her second loan with PEMCI, but her first with Kiva. The first loan of $150 was used to equip her meat shop with essential equipment. With this second loan of $300, she plans to diversify her business into buying and selling cereals such as maize, beans, millet and other fodders.

Through her business, she has been able to promote her church's women's projects in the community. The women's groups are able to plant and export cereals. With time, other members of their A.C.K. church's women's group have been able to gain knowledge and skills and can now impart the skills in their own farms.

Grace is well educated for her community and is concerned in the uplifting of women's affairs. We see her as a key resource person for any other future interventions that PEMCI may wish to undertake with its partners in these communities. Grace is well-worth the support of Kiva partners.

loans.use: To purchase animals for slaughter

loans.name: Bich

texts.en:
Bich is 24 years old and her husband, Binh, is 25. They have a 2 year-old child. The family has no land aside from their home.

To support his family, Binh is a laborer in his village. Bich takes care of their child and sells groceries from home. Because of their low income, only $7-10/person/month, Bich is finding it difficult to keep her grocery store operating.

With a loan of $75 she will be abL. to buy tables, chairs, and other goods that she will then sell from her store. She will repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: Bich wants a loan to purchase some tables and chairs, and other goods to sell at her home.

loans.name: Santos Plutarco

texts.en: In my community I am known as Plutarco, and I sell purified water and deliver it to homes. My largest clients are those people that have small supermarkets, markets, and confectioner’s shops. I sell them water every three days, and my earnings are used to support my family.

loans.use: Purchase of bottled purified water.

loans.name: Sixto

texts.en: My wife and I have been selling fruit in our community for several years. We also sell in schools and on the street. This is our source of income, and it generates revenues so that we can support our children. This summer season we need to stock our business in order to improve our income and finish building our house.

loans.use: Purchase of fresh seasonal fruits like watermelon, melons, mango, oranges, etc.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: My name is Gloria, and, in Honduras, atol (a cornflour drink) and elote (corn) tamales are typical foods. Our entire town eats the corn products we make, and the tourists like the delicious flavors of Choluteca’s streets and boulevards. This income has allowed me to help my children through school and help with the household expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of corn, sugar, flour, water, firewood, cinnamon, milk.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.en: My name is Maria Luisa, and I sell secondhand clothing. Because of my age, I have had to find a way to support myself. For two years, I have been buying and selling quality secondhand clothing. With my earnings I have been able to pay my and my household’s expenses. My goal is to be able to finish paying for my house with sales from this business.

loans.use: Purchase of quality used clothing.

loans.name: Adriana Mercedes

texts.en: I have been working making and selling tortillas for several years, and everyone in my area knows me as Doña Coco. My neighbors and other people who like my tortillas are my clients. With the revenue from my sales I have been able to help my children receive an education and pay for the household expenses.

loans.use: Purchase of water, flour, firewood.

loans.name: Enma Yamileth

texts.en:
I have dedicated myself to the sale of fast food, or "golosinas" as we call it here, for four years. Every afternoon I sell french fries, small cakes, tortillas with fresh cheese, enchiladas, tacos and more. My food sells very quickly, since everyone knows me and likes my treats. I use the income to cover family and business expenses. Now it's vacation time, and a lot of people from other cities are visiting here, so I've hired another person to help me cook and help me sell more of my product.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo cuatro anos de dedicarme a la venta de comidas rapidas, en nuestro pais se le llama golosinas, todas las tardes vendo yuca o papas fritas, pastelitos de harina, tortillas con quesillo, enchiladas, tacos y otros. Mi comida se vende rapido ya que todos me conocen y les gustan mis golosinas. El ingreso que me generan las ventas lo utilizo para cubrir los gastos de mi familia y del negocio. Ahora en temporada de vacaciones nos visitan muchas personas de otras ciudades por lo que contrato otra persona para que me ayude a cocinar y poder vender mas producto.

loans.use: Buy meat, flour, butter, potatoes, condiment, etc.

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
I have been running my small business, a general store that sells popular consumer goods, for five years. Because of my age, I had to look for a business in which I could work and also attend to my husband. The income from the store helps me cover our health and family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo cinco anos de tener mi pequeno negocio en donde vendo productos de consumo popular, por mi edad tuve que buscar un negocio en el que pudiera atender a mi esposo. Con los ingresos que percibo de esta pulperia me ayuda a cubrir nuestros gastos familiares y de salud.

loans.use: Buy milk, bread, eggs, beverages, coffee, sugar, batteries, etc.

loans.name: Jesus Del Carmen

texts.en:
I have been selling used clothing for some years now. In our community there are people with low wages who can only afford to buy second-hand articles to clothe their family. I buy and wash the clothes so they look presentable and can be sold at a higher price, so I can earn enough to provide for my family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace algunos anos me he dedicado a la venta de ropa usada, en nuestra comunidad hay personas que por sus bajos ingresos compran ropa de segunda para suplir la necesidad de ropa de toda la familia, yo compro y lavo la ropa para que se vea presentable y poder venderla a un mejor precio para ganar lo suficiente para mantener a mi familia.

loans.use: Buy shirts, skirts, pants, shorts, T-shirts, etc.

loans.name: Hipolita

texts.en:
For five years I have dedicated myself to the buying and selling of plastic items for the home, office and elsewhere. They almost sell themselves, since a household always needs a pail, bucket or something similar. I sell door to door, which helps me rotate my inventory faster; many people can't leave their house and go to the market and buy the items they need. The income helps me provide for my three kids. I'm a single mother and I must provide for my family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo 5 anos de dedicarme a la compra y venta de articulos de plasticos para el hogar, oficinas y otros. Estos se venden ya que en los hogares siempre se necesita una paila, balde y otros. Yo vendo de puerta en puerta lo que me ayuda a rotar mis productos mas rapido ya que muchas personas no pueden salir de su casa a los mercados a comprar los articulos que necesiten. Mis ingresos me ayudan a mantener a mis 3 hijos ya que soy madre soltera y tengo que mantener a mis familia.

loans.use: Buy pails, buckets, garbage cans, water bottles, etc.

loans.name: Reyna Isabel

texts.en:
For some years now, I have dedicated myself to the making and selling of shirts. I also buy some to sell alongside the ones I make. My sales have increased a lot, and I have started working full time. My clients are pleased with the shirts, and some buy from me wholesale. With the income I recieve from this business I can help with family expenses, namely helping with their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace algunos anos me dedico a la fabricacion y venta de camisetas, tambien compro algunas para venderlas junto a las que confecciono. Mis ventas han mejorado mucho ya que me he dedicado a tiempo completo a este negocio, mis clientes se complacen con las camisetas, algunos me compran al por mayor. Con los ingresos que percibo de este negocio puedo ayudar con los gastos de mi familia y principalmente ayudarles en sus estudios.

loans.use: Buy cloth, thread, etc.

loans.name: Freida

texts.en:
Freida joined Life in Africa in July 2006 as a volunteer with the Internet4Change program. She is a young unmarried lady still staying with her parents. Before she joined, life was not easy because of a lack of full-time employment. At LiA, she has participated in many activities besides the Internet, like craft-making and community leadership work, in which she has excelled. In March 2007, she was offered a full-time position as Marketing Manager for the Life in Africa community.

She now earns a modest community salary of 200,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) per month. (1USD = 1,722 UGX). From the crafts she's learned to make, she earns about 50,000 per month. She is requesting a loan of 250,000 UGX to start a public payphone service in a rented stall near her home. She plans to repay the loan in 3 months.

Freida will be paying her sister 20,000 UGX to help her do the phone business. Since Freida stays at their home, the family is aware of her plans. I met the sister at their home in Kyebando, and she was very happy about the phone business. After paying her sister every month, she will remain with 140,000 UGX.

Freida's project budget is as follows:

1 phone set 150,000 UGX

Renting stall space 30,000 UGX

Airtime 70,000 UGX

Total 250,000 UGX

Freida has also saved 80,000 UGX from her craft sales in recent months, which will help her to meet any unanticipated additional costs for this project.

loans.use: Buying a phone set and renting the operational space.

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is an Acholi lady living in one of the suburbs of Kampala. She is a widow with children under her care. She has migrated from Acholi land, a place that has suffered from war for more than 20 years. She is a long-time member of Life in Africa since 2005. As a member of Life in Africa, she has been very active at the center, especially in the area of handcrafts. She is one of the most dedicated members of paper bead production. She is a cooperative, reliable, and responsible person.

Before Jesca joined Life in Africa, life as a widow was not easy. She had a lot of demands that she could not meet, yet life had to continue. For her efforts to sustain her family, she started a small business of selling charcoal and dried fish. She says her business is doing very well and that they are no losses. Jesca is requesting this loan to use the capital to help boost her on-going business.

She plans to use 150,000 Uganda shillings to buy more charcoal and 100,000 UGX to buy fish. (1USD = 1,722 UGX). She expects to make a profit of 200,000 UGX from the entire business. She currently makes a profit of 120,000 UGX. She earns a profit of 80,000 UGX from charcoal and 40,000 UGX from selling the dry fish. She does the work herself, and there is no need to employ anyone.

LOAN BUDGET

1)Buying charcoal 150,000 UGX

2)Buying dry fish 100,000 UGX

Total 250,000 UGX

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence O. is a widow with three children. She has been a member of Life in Africa since 2006. As a member of Life in Africa, she has been very active in the organization, and she has proven to be a hardworking, committed, helpful, responsible and reliable person.

Florence is asking for a loan of 250,000 UGX to operate a business of selling and supplying groundnuts and simsim paste. (1USD = 1,722 UGX). She will use the loan to buy the necessary materials, hire casual labor, and pay for transportation.

Florence has been running this small-scale business, and now she would like to expand it. That is why she applied for the loan. Through the paste business, Florence expects to raise 270,000 UGX monthly from the business. She currently makes a profit of 120,000 monthly.

The sesame paste she makes is packed in different sized containers. Each container has it's own price, ranging from 1000 UGX to 3000 UGX. Her target customers are mainly super markets, schools and households.

Florence doesn't plan to employ anyone for a long time. She plans to do most of the work by herself. She says the work involved in the business is not so much that it would require her to employ someone else.

LOAN BUDGET

1. Raw materials (simsim and groundnuts ) 180,000 UGX

2. Package containers 50,000 UGX

3. Casual Labour 10000 UGX

4. Firewood 10000 UGX

Total 250,000 Uganda shillings

loans.use: Buying materials and transportation

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet O. is a young married lady living in one of the suburbs of Kampala. She comes from the northern part of Uganda, a place that has experienced war for over 20 years. She moved away from this area as a young girl, searching for security, safety and survival. She settled in Kampala.

Harriet is a lady with a passion to work hard for survival and sustenance. She has been a member of Life in Africa since 2006, and she is very active in the center. She is a supportive and responsible person who is also good at planning activities. Over time, she has developed the skill to face challenges and overcome them.

Before Harriet joined Life in Africa, life was not easy in terms of general welfare. In her efforts to sustain herself, she searched for work. The work she discovered was with the stone quarry, where she did the stone digging and cracking. She was paid for the work she did. After some time of working at the stone quarry and witnessing others' success, Harriet got the idea to start her own stone quarry business. The stone-selling business is doing very well because of the massive developments of construction taking place.

The stone quarry business involves digging stones, cracking them into the desired sizes depending on the client's order, and delivering the cracked stones to the customers. Currently, Harriet has been producing two deliveries of stones supplied, getting a monthly profit of 90,000 Uganda shillings (UGX). (1USD = 1,722 UGX). She has been making two deliveries only due to limited capital. In order to be able to expand her business, she decided to ask for the loan. She expects to get an 45,000 UGX per delivery of stones made on a monthly basis.

To be able to succeed in this business, Harriet is planning to employ people to do the work as it is explained below in the budget.

LOAN BUDGET

For one (1) trip

1)Digging stone 20,000 UGX

2)Transfer fee 7,000 UGX

3)Cracking fee 32,000 UGX

TOTAL 59,000 UGX

She plans to do 4 trips 59,000x4= 236,000 UGX

4)Extra balance/ emergency 14,000 UGX

Total 250,000/=

loans.use: Facilitating laborers - stone digging and cracking

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph M. is a young unmarried man whose parents died and left him at a tender age. He started coming to Life in Africa by serving the community food. Through that business, he became interested in the activities at Life in Africa. Due to his good services, he was invited to join and become a full Life in Africa member.

He started by counting materials and then later making bracelets for the Invisible Children campaign. His lifestyle has improved because he earns a lot more than what he made from the previous business.

Since he has sisters who are still jobless at home, he wants to start a pay phone business to help them. He thus wishes to get a loan of 250,000 Uganda shillings, which he will pay back in 5 months. (1USD = 1,722 UGX). From the business, he will earn about 130,000 UGX.

His budget is as follows:

Telephone set 150,000 UGX

Sister to operate 20,000 UGX

Renting space 20,000 UGX

Airtime 50,000 UGX

contingencies 10,000 UGX

Total 250,000 UGX

loans.use: Buying a phone set and airtime

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lenders to Life in Africa borrowers in Uganda,

On behalf of Life in Africa's WE Center Kampala community I offer an apology for the irregularities in posting our borrower repayments and journal updates to the Kiva website over the past several months. In an effort to model a high standard of the transparency we operating in Africa should uphold online, this rather long message contains details that are relevant to helping you understand what's already happened, and what's happening now in the Life in Africa community with regard to this issue. Rest assured, Kiva staff are aware of these issues and some have personally met, face to face, a number of the personalities involved. We at LiA feel it's now high time to let you - our valued lenders - in on the sensitive nature of the challenges we've been dealing with.

In September 2006, some LiA community members tasked to manage the loan program and the Invisible Children bracelet campaign resigned amidst accusations of mismanagement from other members in the Life in Africa community. In the process, which was painful but arguably very healthy for the community in important ways, a laptop was stolen that included the records for both programs, the WE Center was closed for 2 weeks, and management of the invisible children project shifted to another site, taking 35 (of 80) Life in Africa members involved in the project with them to be full time employees. Among the staff lost during all the disruption at that time included 4 of 7 people trained to process and manage LiA member loans. Those who were left with loans training were heaped with mountains of new community management responsibilities on their plates. Everything related to the loans program seemed upside down and got out of synch for a while.

Most LiA borrowers experienced a 1-3 month period after the September events when payments due to them from the Invisible Children bracelet project were delayed. Many fell into arrears on their loans at that time. In most (but not all) of those cases, those arrears have now been paid up to date. However, in the wake of September's disruption, the paper files for the loan program were also left in disarray and the computerized records were gone. It took over 3 months for David Ewaku, a Life in Africa Board Member, to reconstruct the records and get the partnerships with Kiva (esp. online) and Invisible Children somewhat back on track, so that by January 2007 loan payments were coming in smoothly again.

Unfortunately, part of why it took so long was that David fell very ill and has been in and out of hospital since November. By then, however, we had hired a recent MBA grad with experience in microfinance as full time accounts manager for the Life in Africa community. Yet another disaster - the new accounts manager took over David's updated loan program records, and proceeded through professional incompetence to make a complete mess of them over the next 4 months. She resigned in mid-March 2007 after receiving a warning letter from the community operations team about her performance. We now find ourselves consulting 3 different sources of information that are riddled with holes and mistakes in order to get an accurate picture of what our borrowers have actually paid.

After a recent telephone discussion with Kiva staff about the apparent arrears in our loan portfolio, and with me hosting meetings in my home and participating in an advisory team for organizing Kiva's forthcoming ground-truthing efforts in East Africa this past week, we at LiA have been feeling a very keen sense of urgency about updating our payments on the Kiva website. Luckily, the community has Grace - our star community leader/borrower who is featured in the PBS Frontline segment about Kiva. Over the past 2 years, she has dedicated her heart and soul to uplifting Life in Africa's communities in both Kampala and Gulu. Though she is no accountant, Grace Ayaa has now committed herself to taking the LiA loan program's administrative challenges by the horns.

Over the past 2 weeks Grace has been working with a small group of community members to figure out how to reconstruct the community's loan program records, so that more than one person understands the process that's been used and everyone can agree on the final updated report. I can see she is very determined to do this transparently and am grateful on behalf of the LiA community to Grace for the leadership she's investing in getting our payment and loan tracking system straight and systemized once and for all. In fact, she had hoped to finish everything before leaving for a short trip to Gulu this morning. Instead, Grace and her group of committee members have asked me to appeal directly for lenders' patience. They feel that getting this sorted out right means it should not be approached in haste - they need more time to talk to the borrowers one by one to compare their records & recollections with the office records to get an accurate final picture of where each member stands.

PLEASE NOTE: To avoid that ALL of our members' online records are negatively affected any further by this internal administrative crisis, we are today marking all scheduled member loan payments as paid up to this month on the Kiva website. The amount paid on each account has been determined by the Kiva bulk-payments feature as the scheduled amount outstanding due to Kiva. Our community has, after all, guaranteed that each of these loans will be fully repaid to the lenders, regardless of each borrower's actual performance. Nonetheless, once we have all of this sorted out, we will update all of you (hopefully with next month's payments) on the accurate situation for your borrower with a link to the full and actual member repayment records for all loans guaranteed by the LiA community in 2006. In the cases where payments posted on Kiva were already up to date, I have posted a $1 payment to be able to alert all of our lenders to this message.

I humbly hope you can forgive us at LiA for not communicating with lenders earlier about the challenges we've faced in keeping the payments on Kiva accurately recorded, and thank you for your continued patience as the community works in good faith to get the mess sorted out. It is likely Kiva will be sending a Kiva Fellow to work with us during the summer months, which - combined with the lessons we've already learned - will undoubtedly help us stay on a better track as we now begin raising loan funds for more members in both Kampala and Gulu.

Meanwhile, any lenders with constructive support to offer, or with an interest in volunteering with our microfinance program in Uganda, are most welcome to join us in dialogue at the Omidyar.net communuty and contact Grace Ayaa online at http://www.omidyar.net/group/lia/. You can also see an interview with Grace about the challenges of leading the LiA community at http://www.youtube.com/v/KhqXHgl7j-k.

Many thanks again for the lasting impact you have made on our member's life, and on our community's ability to learn how to enable and manage access to micro-loans for our members.

Sincerely

Christina Jordan
Founder & Managing Director
Life in Africa - WE Centers Uganda
http://www.LifeInAfrica.com

P.S. - Watch out for Life in Africa borrowers from WE Center Gulu in Northern Uganda, coming online with loan applications at kiva within the next 2 weeks. There is a recently made student movie about the WE Center Gulu community building activities LiA started there in August 2007 at http://www.youtube.com/v/maG0Hd9jh6o - Enjoy!

loans.name: Jiponi

texts.en:
Jiponi O. is married with two children and an Acholi by tribe. He was born in Pader district and came to Kampala in October 2002 due to the rebel war which was terrible in that region of Northern Uganda and led to displacement of many people like him. When he came to Kampala, he had to settle in Acholi quarters where most of the displaced Acholi people live.

While in Acholi quarters, he was working as a private security guard with the Hwan Sung company. That job came to an end when the company decided to recruit guards from a security organization. He had nothing to do until he joined the women in the Acholi quarters in making paper beads. That paved way for him to join Life in Africa in September 2006 when there was a position open for a security guard. He worked as a security guard in Life in Africa until February 2007 when he was given a position in a craft production team that earns him a better living.

Since he joined the organization, he has been so helpful to the organization and the other members. Through others members who have acquired this loan, he has seen how a small loan can change someone's life. That has inspired him to also try.

For his plan, he has discovered that building materials like stone are in a higher demand than ever before as there is massive construction and renovation of houses and roads in Kampala to meet the Commonwealth heads of government conference (CHOGM) due November 2007 in Uganda.

The Acholi Quarter is located on a rocky hill, where stone can be easily sourced and laborers who know this work are available. When Jiponi gets this loan, he will begin by paying for the site right away, then hire people to dig out the stones. This may take him about a week. Then he will have the stones moved out of the pit, while those doing the crushing are also doing their part. In a week, the stones will be out, and about one and a quarter deliveries may be ready for sale, making a total of three deliveries per month. This work does not need much supervision, so all measurements and payments of laborers shall be done by him when he gets back home in the evenings.

To make this project successful, he is seeking loan in the amount of 250,000 Uganda shillings (UGX), and he will be able to repay in six months. (1 USD = 1,722 UGX). Jiponi hopes to make a profit of 150,000 UGX per month. Below is his estimated budget:

Hiring a site..........20,000 UGX

Extraction labor.......20,000 UGX per delivery

Porters........... 7,000 UGX per delivery

Crushing labor ........ 32,000 UGX per delivery

Sub-total = 79000 x 3 deliveries..... 237,000 UGX per month

Contingencies ........ 13,000 UGX

Total................250,000 UGX

loans.use: Renting a stone quarry site and digging out stones

loans.name: Amisi

texts.en:
Amisi B. is a very active member of Life in Africa. He joined in 2004 as a member. Since then, he has been so dedicated and hard-working. He has been quick to participate in community initiatives and has learned how to make hand crafts such as banana fibered balls, bracelets out of organic materials, and many other things. Among the things he likes is serving God. He is somebody who is helpful to the community, often translating at meetings into the Luganda language for other members who don't understand English.

Since the loan scheme began in Life in Africa, he has never rushed but has been very active at the loan review meetings to learn how to make a good loan plan. His plan is to purchase one public pay phone.

Once his loan request is accepted and funded, he will locate his business at Ntinda stage, where there are a large number of public pay phone users. To compete with his counter-parts, he is not going to charge as much. He has learned that all the public pay phone attendants charge 300 Uganda shillings (UGX) for mtn to mtn network per 56 seconds and across other networks for 400 -500 per 56 sec. Amisi plans to charge 200 UGX and 300 UGX for these services instead. He has a brother willing to operate the phone and expects to make a monthly profit of 60,000 UGX after paying his brother.

He is seeking a loan amount of two hundred and fifty thousand shillings, and he will repay the loan in 12 months. (1 USD = 1,722 UGX) Below is his budget:

Purchase of one public pay phone @ ...... 200,000 UGX

Ground rent for four months @ 10,000 UGX per month.....40,000 UGX

Stool for putting the phones................10,000 UGX

Total 250,000 UGX

loans.use: Purchase of pay phone

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. is a Muganda by tribe. She was working in a salon as a hair dresser that closed down when it was not able to pay the high trading license fee to the Kampala city council.

She was unemployed at home until her sister Annet Nansubuga, a Life in Africa member, called her to come and join the Life in Africa community and become involved in the community initiatives. When she stepped in Life in Africa community group, she saw it was a true life in Africa. The first thing that interested her was finding people dressed in African attire and making handcrafts as the best tool to sustain themselves. She was so inspired by the activities at LiA that she started learning what others were doing. She is a person who is quick to learn, and there is no doubt that she is now among the experts in bracelet-making and paper beads production.

Margaret has a brother who is jobless but who has experience in selling second-hand clothes at Owino Market in town. Her plan is to set up a used clothing business with her brother, who will run the business. She is seeking a loan amount of 250,000 Uganda shillings that she will repay in 10 months. (1 USD = 1,722 UGX). She expects to earn 180,000 UGX per month to add to her own income after paying her brother.

Below is her budget:

-Second hand clothes for 100,000 UGX

-Second hand ladies shoes for 100,000 UGX

-Stall rent for 2 months 40000 UGX

-Transport 10,000 UGX

Total 250,000 Uganda shillings

loans.use: Buying and selling ladies second-hand shoes and clothes

loans.name: Ally

texts.en:
Ally sells used clothes in a busy area of Ilala district of Dar es Salaam. He has five years experience in this business. He buys bundles of used clothes from wholesalers, repairs and cleans them before he offers them for resale. This business has helped him generate income for his family of a wife and three children.

He wants to diversify his business by adding shoes. His strategy requires an expansion of the current premise, buying a stock of shoes and a reserve of working capital.

Ally is well known in his area and he is sure to make good sales with this new business. A loan of USD550 will help him implement the strategy.

loans.use: Add stock of clothes

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is married and has two children. She makes and sells pillows. She obtains sponge materials from mattress-making industries and prepares pillow cases herself. Her pillows are so good that one cannot tell that they are hand made. Asha has been in this business for three years now.

She recently received an order from a nearby region of Morogoro after sending a sample of twenty pillows. What she can produce is only ten percent of what is needed. A loan of USD550 will help her meet the demand.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Thú

texts.en:
Mrs Thu is 68 years old. Her husband died a long time ago. Now she lives with her son, who is 39 years old. Her son is a day laborer but the work is not stable.

She doesn’t have any land for cultivation so it is difficult for her family to earn a living. She has to sell noodles for breakfast to earn a living. She wants to borrow US $75 for this business.

loans.use: To sell noodles for breakfast

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.en:
Maimuna lives in the Mtakuja area of Dar es Salaam. She operates a mobile food vending business. She produces food at home, packs the food and distributes it to various customers she has, especially office workers and school children.

She plans to improve her business by adding sufficient numbers of food serving dishes, packaging materials and a stock of food. Recently, with the help of her friend, she obtained orders to serve two more offices located at the industrial area. More working capital is needed. To facilitate her plan Prisca needs USD550.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Eroo

texts.en:
Eroo is married with ten children, and all are in primary school. She is a primary school dropout and has not undertaken any form of training.
